title: Getting Started with splineplot
text: splineplot package provides unified interface visualizing spline effects various regression models. vignette guide basic usage package.

title: Getting Started with splineplot
text: First, let’s create sample data work :
code: set.seed(42) n <- 500  # Continuous predictor age <- rnorm(n, mean = 50, sd = 10)  # Non-linear effect true_effect <- -0.05*(age - 50) + 0.001*(age - 50)^3/100  # Various outcomes time_to_event <- rexp(n, rate = exp(true_effect)) event_status <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.8) binary_outcome <- rbinom(n, 1, plogis(true_effect)) count_outcome <- rpois(n, lambda = exp(true_effect/2)) continuous_outcome <- true_effect + rnorm(n, 0, 0.5)  # Create data frame data <- data.frame(   age = age,   time = time_to_event,   status = event_status,   binary = binary_outcome,   count = count_outcome,   continuous = continuous_outcome )

title: Getting Started with splineplot
text: GAM Cox family useful flexible modeling survival data:  plot shows: - smooth effect age hazard - 95% confidence intervals (dotted lines) - reference point (diamond) HR = 1 - Histogram showing distribution data
code: # Fit GAM Cox model using weights gam_cox <- gam(time ~ s(age),                family = cox.ph(),                weights = status,                data = data)  # Create spline plot splineplot(gam_cox, data,           ylim = c(0.5, 2.0),           xlab = "Age (years)",           ylab = "Hazard Ratio") #> Using 'age' as x variable #> Using refx = 49.62 (median of age) #> Warning: Removed 71 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_line()`). #> Warning: Removed 67 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_line()`). #> Warning: Removed 79 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_line()`).

title: Getting Started with splineplot
text: package automatically detects visualizes interaction terms:
code: # Add a grouping variable data$group <- factor(sample(c("Male", "Female"), n, replace = TRUE))  # Fit model with interaction gam_interact <- gam(time ~ s(age, by = group),                    family = cox.ph(),                    weights = status,                    data = data)  # Plot shows separate curves for each group splineplot(gam_interact, data,           ylim = c(0.5, 2.0)) #> Using 'age' as x variable #> Detected interaction with 'group' #> Using refx = 49.62 (median of age) #> Warning: No shared levels found between `names(values)` of the manual scale and the #> data's fill values. #> Warning: Removed 165 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_line()`). #> Warning: Removed 111 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_line()`). #> Warning: Removed 150 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_line()`).

title: Getting Started with splineplot
text: Model Choice: Use GAM maximum flexibility, GLM splines parametric approach Degrees Freedom: Higher df allows flexibility may overfit Reference Point: Choose meaningful reference value interpretation Confidence Intervals: Ribbon style visually appealing, dotted lines show precision better Sample Size: Ensure adequate sample size stable spline estimates

title: Create Publication-Ready Spline Effect Plots
text: splineplot package provides unified interface visualizing spline effects GAM (Generalized Additive Models) GLM (Generalized Linear Models) R. creates publication-ready plots confidence intervals, supporting various model types including Linear, Logistic, Poisson, Cox proportional hazards models.

title: Create Publication-Ready Spline Effect Plots
text: 📊 Unified visualization spline effects across different model types 🎨 Publication-ready plots customizable aesthetics 📈 Automatic detection spline terms interaction variables 🔄 Support multiple spline types: GAM smooths (s(), te(), ti()), GLM splines (ns(), bs()), Cox pspline() 📉 Flexible confidence intervals: dotted lines ribbon style 📊 Built-histograms showing data distribution 🎯 Reference point marking automatic SE = 0 reference value 🔀 Interaction term support -variable visualization

title: Create Publication-Ready Spline Effect Plots
text: can install released version splineplot CRAN: install development version GitHub:
code: install.packages("splineplot") # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("jinseob2kim/splineplot")

title: Create Publication-Ready Spline Effect Plots
code: library(splineplot) library(mgcv) library(survival) library(splines) library(ggplot2)  # Generate sample data set.seed(123) n <- 500 x <- rnorm(n, mean = 35, sd = 8) lp <- -0.06*(x - 35) + 0.0009*(x - 35)^3/(8^2) time <- rexp(n, rate = exp(lp)) status <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.8) binary_y <- rbinom(n, 1, plogis(lp))  dat <- data.frame(x, time, status, binary_y)

title: Create Publication-Ready Spline Effect Plots
code: # Fit GAM Cox model fit_gam_cox <- gam(time ~ s(x),                    family = cox.ph(), weights = status, data = dat)  # Create spline plot splineplot(fit_gam_cox, dat,           ylim = c(0.2, 2.0),           xlab = "Age (years)",           ylab = "Hazard Ratio") #> Using 'x' as x variable #> Using refx = 35.17 (median of x) #> Warning: Removed 67 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_line()`). #> Warning: Removed 56 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_line()`). #> Warning: Removed 62 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_line()`).

title: Create Publication-Ready Spline Effect Plots
code: # Fit logistic model with natural splines fit_glm <- glm(binary_y ~ ns(x, df = 4),                family = binomial(), data = dat)  # Create spline plot splineplot(fit_glm, dat,           ylim = c(0.2, 2.0),           ylab = "Odds Ratio") #> Using 'x' as x variable #> Using refx = 35.17 (median of x) #> Warning: Removed 37 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_line()`). #> Warning: Removed 85 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_line()`). #> Warning: Removed 59 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_line()`).

title: Create Publication-Ready Spline Effect Plots
code: # Add a grouping variable dat$group <- factor(sample(c("A", "B"), n, replace = TRUE))  # Fit model with interaction fit_interaction <- gam(time ~ s(x, by = group),                       family = cox.ph(),                       weights = status,                       data = dat)  # Plot with interaction splineplot(fit_interaction, dat,           ylim = c(0.2, 2.0)) #> Using 'x' as x variable #> Detected interaction with 'group' #> Using refx = 35.17 (median of x) #> Warning: No shared levels found between `names(values)` of the manual scale and the #> data's fill values. #> Warning: Removed 136 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_line()`). #> Warning: Removed 116 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_line()`). #> Warning: Removed 126 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_line()`).

title: Extract Spline Data — extract_spline_data
code: # Create sample data set.seed(123) n <- 100 x <- rnorm(n, mean = 50, sd = 10) y <- rbinom(n, 1, plogis(-0.05*(x - 50))) dat <- data.frame(x = x, y = y)  # Fit GLM with splines library(splines) fit <- glm(y ~ ns(x, df = 4), family = binomial(), data = dat)  # Extract spline data model_info <- list(type = "glm", family = "binomial", ylabel = "Odds Ratio") df <- extract_spline_data(fit, dat, "x", refx = 50, model_info,                           log_scale = FALSE, ci_level = 0.95) head(df) #>          x        y        lcl       ucl     ylabel #> 1 26.90831 4.820616 -0.9214519 10.562684 Odds Ratio #> 2 27.13427 4.738736 -0.8847702 10.362242 Odds Ratio #> 3 27.36022 4.656878 -0.8483307 10.162086 Odds Ratio #> 4 27.58618 4.575062 -0.8121642  9.962289 Odds Ratio #> 5 27.81213 4.493311 -0.7763023  9.762925 Odds Ratio #> 6 28.03809 4.411646 -0.7407771  9.564069 Odds Ratio

what: Spline Plot for GAM and GLM Models — splineplot
title: Spline Plot for GAM and GLM Models — splineplot
text: Create ggplot2 visualizations smooth spline effects GAM GLM models. Supports Linear, Logistic, Poisson, Cox models interaction terms. Handles GAM smooth terms (s(), te(), ti()), GLM splines (ns(), bs()), Cox pspline().

title: Spline Plot for GAM and GLM Models — splineplot
code: splineplot(   fit,   data,   xvar = NULL,   by_var = NULL,   refx = NULL,   term_index = 1,   bins = 12,   xlim = NULL,   ylim = NULL,   show_hist = NULL,   log_scale = FALSE,   ci_level = 0.95,   show_ref_point = TRUE,   colors = NULL,   ribbon_ci = FALSE,   xlab = NULL,   ylab = NULL,   ylab_right = "Percent of Population" )

title: Spline Plot for GAM and GLM Models — splineplot
text: fit fitted model object (gam, glm, lm, coxph) data data frame used fit model xvar Character string specifying variable name x-axis (default: first spline term) by_var Character string specifying interaction variable (default: auto-detect model) refx Reference value x variable (default: median) term_index GAM multiple smooth terms, term plot (default: 1) bins Number bins histogram (default: 12) xlim X-axis limits (default: range x variable) ylim Y-axis limits (default: auto-determined, e.g., c(0.25, 2.0) HR//RR) show_hist Logical, whether show histogram (default: TRUE) log_scale Logical, whether use log scale /RR/HR (default: FALSE) ci_level Confidence interval level (default: 0.95) show_ref_point Logical, whether show reference point marker (default: TRUE) colors Named vector colors by_var levels ribbon_ci Logical, whether use ribbon style CI (default: FALSE, uses dotted lines) xlab Custom x-axis label (default: xvar name) ylab Custom y-axis label (default: auto-determined based model type) ylab_right Custom right y-axis label histogram (default: "Percent Population")

title: Spline Plot for GAM and GLM Models — splineplot
text: ggplot2 object

title: Spline Plot for GAM and GLM Models — splineplot
code: # Create sample data set.seed(123) n <- 200 x <- rnorm(n, mean = 50, sd = 10) lp <- -0.05*(x - 50) + 0.001*(x - 50)^2 y <- rbinom(n, 1, plogis(lp)) dat <- data.frame(x = x, y = y)  # GLM with natural splines library(splines) fit_glm <- glm(y ~ ns(x, df = 4), family = binomial(), data = dat) p <- splineplot(fit_glm, dat) #> Using 'x' as x variable #> Using refx = 49.41 (median of x)  # \donttest{ # GAM example (requires mgcv) if (requireNamespace("mgcv", quietly = TRUE)) {   fit_gam <- mgcv::gam(y ~ s(x), family = binomial(), data = dat)   p2 <- splineplot(fit_gam, dat) } #> Using 'x' as x variable #> Using refx = 49.41 (median of x)  # Cox model example (requires survival) if (requireNamespace("survival", quietly = TRUE)) {   time <- rexp(n, rate = exp(lp/2))   status <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.8)   dat$time <- time   dat$status <- status   fit_cox <- survival::coxph(survival::Surv(time, status) ~ ns(x, df = 4),                               data = dat)   p3 <- splineplot(fit_cox, dat) } #> Using 'x' as x variable #> Using refx = 49.41 (median of x) # }
